results.title: Amongst equals
results.creator_credit: Tom Zubrycki, Paul Hamfess and Jotz Productions
results.brief_description: Documents the history of the Australian Trade Union Movement. The film is not endorsed by the ACTU and represents only the film maker’s view. The 1850s saw the introduction of the eight hour labour movement and the subsequent development of the trade union movement. Unions were established to organise, assert and defend the worker’s rights, industrial awards, occupational health and safety and minimum wages.

results.title: Aboriginal dreaming stories
results.brief_description: Jointly presented by Francis Firebrace Jones and Paulin Mcleod, these stories are presented with great enthusiasm and in the spirit of enhancing respect for the land and the Aboriginal people of Australia. The story titles are: In the beginning ; Creation of day and night ; Who discovered Australia? ; How fire came to Earth ; Giant Goanna and the Little black snake ; Why does the kookaburra laugh ; Old bush turkey ; Sharing time ; How the kangaroo got its pouch ; The Platypus ; Death of a cockatoo ; Walkabout ; The Bunyip ; “the Wallagara Man.

results.title: Play Safe
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board, Australian Road Safety Council and Video Films
results.brief_description: Aimed at children, this film highlights a number of road safety aspects. Don Bradman talks to the children about avoiding accidents, both going and coming from school, and during playtime on the school playground.

results.title: The Bad society
results.brief_description: In December 1976, 16,000 people converged at the Cotter River in Canberra for the “Down to earth” festival; a conference on alternative lifestyles. In attendance were Reverend George Davies, Dr. Jim Cairns, Dr. Jim Falk as well as thousands of counter culture followers. This documentary explores the festival and the themes of politics and social change. The Philisophy of Ex Deputy Prime Minister, Dr. Jim Cairns is particularly focussed on with its emphasis on how a nation state creates a ‘bad society’ and how communal life and a counter culture lifestyle forms the only radicalism against society.

results.title: They took the children away: Aboriginal family experience
results.brief_description: Tens of thousands of Aboriginal children have been taken from their families. The removal of indigenous children has had devastating effects on the traditional family life of Aboriginal communities. Three Aboriginal people interviewed in this program talk about their own experiences in a hope to create awareness and understanding between Aboroginal and non-Aboriginal Australians.

results.title: Tramways
results.creator_credit: Leonie Dickinson, Michael Bau and Gunzel
results.brief_description: A warm hearted look at the people of Melbourne, their trams and their passion. Delves into the fascination with a mode of transport that carries passengers in the 19990’s on 1930’s vehicles.

results.title: Neat on Paper
results.creator_credit: James Kesteven, Mandy King, Miriana Marusic and Sydney Filmmakers' Co-op Action Group
results.brief_description: The Sydney Filmmakers’ Co-operative was a major national agency for the distribution and exhibition of independently produced Australian film and video for over 20 years. This program examines the issues surrounding its closure in 1986.

results.title: Australian animals dreaming stories
results.brief_description: First Nations peoples used stories to teach their children about the laws and myths of their land. Pauline McLeod tells five stories about unique Australian animals. Each story is laced with colourful drawings. The stories featured are: ‘The Giant goanna and the black snake’; ‘The Platypus’; ‘How the kangaroo got its pouch’; ‘Why does the kookaburra laugh?’; ‘The Bunyip’.

results.title: Bushland fantasy
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board and Soundmasters
results.brief_description: Provides glimpses of the many wild flowers and animals found in the Australian bush. Includes photographs of native flora, and animal life such as kangaroos, wallabies, platypus, lyrebirds and koalas. Many of these can be found in the wildlife sanctuary at Healesville where special efforts are made to arrange a proper diet for these animals. Narrated by John Dudley.
